Jack Mosley.Action: Accepts the responsibility to babysit the crime scene alone until uniformed officers arrive.
Sits down calmly with a bottle of Cutty Sark and reads the news while waiting.
Follows orders to babysit the crime scene and does not leave until sealed, showing adherence to duty.
Arrives limping, out of shape and flushed from climbing stairs, indicating possible physical limitation but still completing the task.
Covers his nose with a handkerchief and methodically checks cabinets before settling down to wait with a bottle and newspaper.
Sits down and begins reading a newspaper while waiting, possibly showing patience or detachment rather than proactive vigilance.
Ignores an important remark about making sure to put the right dates on a wire request form, showing disregard for procedural detail.
Avoids Lieutenant Kincaid by slipping out of the coffee room and down the stairs like a kid without a hall pass, showing evasive and unprofessional behavior.
Shows casual confidence interacting with Grace, negotiating his schedule and handling minor tasks, indicating some basic workplace competence and comfort.
Notices an elderly widow sitting alone; attempts to retrieve and preserve personal belongings (photo album) left behind.
Avoids eye contact after seeing the widow’s distress and walks away.
Argues with Lieutenant Kincaid about being assigned a minor task while off duty and fatigued.
Notices the elderly woman’s photo album left behind and retrieves it, ensuring it is handed to a uniformed officer to return to the interview room.
Reluctantly accepts an inconvenient assignment from Lieutenant Kincaid despite being off the clock and wanting to avoid it.
Tries to pass off the assignment to other officers who are on light duty, showing an attempt to avoid responsibility.
Engages in a blunt, somewhat insubordinate exchange with his superior, Lieutenant Kincaid, which fails to assert his position effectively.
Turns up the radio and ignores Eddie's moral question, acting dismissive and avoiding the conversation.
Hits the accelerator and abruptly changes direction, showing impatience and disregard for Eddie's inquiry.
Responds brusquely to Eddie telling him to 'shut up' and dismisses hypothetical scenarios by claiming they do not apply to him.
Questions Eddie sharply about the deal he received implying suspicion or cynicism.
Dismisses Eddie’s attempt at explaining himself, calling him a rat.
Ignores Eddie's comments about being where he's supposed to be.
Double parks the car, shuts off the engine, prepares to leave despite Eddie’s situation.
Fumbles for cash, implying a willingness to help financially.
Exchanges pleasantries with the Chinese store owners in broken Chinese, sharing a moment of friendliness and showing effort to connect.
Makes a sarcastic comment about the witness escort handbook, showing a somewhat playful attitude.
Kills the Wiry Russian in self-defense after the Russian fired a Tech-9 at him and others.
Shows fear and shock with gun hand shaking and tunnel vision after shooting.
Rushes to help Eddie to safety despite gunfire and chaos.
Explains the jimmied lock and security monitor clearly, showing understanding and communication skills.
Successfully shoots the attacker, demonstrating quick reaction and marksmanship.
Experiences tunnel vision and audio collapse after shooting, indicating momentary loss of composure.
Notices the incoming threat in time to hear the chamber explode and evade the fatal shot, showing situational awareness.
Charges toward the Impala under fire despite disorientation, showing physical courage but possibly impaired tactical judgment.
Fumbles for the radio and drops it while under fire and glass shards raining down, showing some loss of fine motor control under stress.
Manages to start the car and drive in reverse while under fire, demonstrating resilience and composure under extreme pressure.
Kicks open passenger door, pulls Eddie Bunker onto the sidewalk to protect him from danger.
Stumbles and struggles to protect Eddie despite physical limitations (bad leg).
Chases after Eddie when he runs back toward danger, screaming to warn him.
Yanks Eddie to the sidewalk to protect him from traffic and danger.
Shakes the fuzziness, trying to remember procedures and keep Eddie safe in dangerous situations.
Pulls an elderly bar owner, Dominic Forlini, to safety when a bat is thrown.
Uses curt and harsh language ('Are you fucking nuts!') towards Eddie.
Roughly hauls Eddie, calls him 'rats' and 'bottom feeders', and says 'Shoulda let them kill you'
Operates on instinct to protect himself and control the situation (closing curtains, hiding)
Pulls the trigger to save himself and others, shows hesitation and inner turmoil but acts decisively to stop Jerry Shue from shooting.
Turns his back and avoids watching the violent scene unfolding, indicating discomfort and possible emotional detachment.
Calms the surprised laundry owner in broken Chinese to avoid suspicion.
Unlocks Eddie’s cuffs and provides him with clean clothes to help him blend in.
Instructs Eddie calmly on how to walk and behaves protectively by staying close behind him.
Watches his surroundings carefully while escorting Eddie, showing a sense of responsibility.
Tells Eddie to 'pick it up' and pressures him to move faster, showing impatience.
Is attentive to their situation, searching actively for a cab to help them progress.
Is walking closely and protectively with Eddie, staying just off his left shoulder.
Takes a sarcastic but non-hostile remark from Eddie in stride: 'None taken.'
Notices Eddie’s serious concern and tries to stay aware of the situation, though distracted initially.
Shows awareness of surroundings by quickly looking for Eddie when he notices him gone.
Observes the street scene and cops carefully from inside the bakery, demonstrating vigilance.
Appears distracted and not fully listening when Eddie explains the urgency of getting somewhere by noon.
Pulls Eddie close and warns him that this isn’t a game and to keep it together or they’re both dead.
Says nothing when Eddie holds out the business card and talks about the significance of the bakery girl and signs.
Pulls Eddie close and warns him 'This isn’t a game asshole. Keep it together or we’re both dead.'
Says nothing in response to Eddie’s signs and theories, appearing reserved or withholding judgment.
Limping but hurrying up stairs as fast as his broken body can take him, showing determination despite injury.
Shows frustration but does not express anger toward Eddie; lets Eddie search the apartment beside him.
Reacts with a flash of hurt and sadness when confronted with his past personal items but quickly recovers.
Searches for a hidden key but does not find it; admits frustration shortly after.
Successfully picks a complex Medeco dead bolt open using a dry cleaning hanger, demonstrating lock-picking skill.
Dismisses Eddie's attempt and criticism, pushing past him to continue the search confidently.
Rummages through the living room closet but comes out empty handed, indicating difficulty locating the item.
Shows emotional control by quickly masking a flash of hurt and sadness upon seeing personal reminders in the closet.
Hits the sidewalk immediately after doors bang open, moves quickly across busy streets trying to think and locate a target in a crowd.
Chuckles to himself, shows a moment of lightheartedness.
Says 'Trust me' warning about plans going wrong, demonstrating candidness.
Labels Eddie as a thief and predicts he will always be one, a blunt and somewhat judgmental statement.
Refuses to let Eddie use the phone to call the ADA, pulls him from the cab to avoid capture, showing protective instincts.
Pulls Eddie into the electronics store suddenly, showing protective behavior.
Struggles to keep pace despite his limp, pushing through pain.
Glares at Eddie after hearing about amputation story, showing irritation or impatience.
Calls Eddie a 'sunny little shit' with a tone that suggests some affectionate teasing.
Hesitates before jumping over a wide alley but eventually complies with Eddie's urging.
Clasps Eddie’s forearm to save him from falling four stories despite his own bad hand.
Shoves Eddie back against the wall to protect him from gunfire.
Warns Eddie not to jump into the dumpster, expressing concern for his safety.
Dismisses Eddie's hope by stating 'There’s no we in this,' indicating a somewhat cold or detached stance.
Jumps quickly out of the way of gunfire, landing firmly on steel flooring, demonstrating physical awareness and agility.
Clutches Eddie’s forearm with his bad hand to stop him from falling, showing quick reflexes and presence of mind despite injury.
Commands Eddie to drop the notebook to reduce risk, indicating awareness and attempt to control the situation.
Fails to prevent Eddie from jumping despite clear danger, possibly reflecting limited control or underestimated risk.
Advocates caution and realistic assessment of danger (highlighting the dumpster is not a safe place), showing situational awareness and practical judgment.
Shoves Eddie back against the wall for cover when threat emerges, showing protective instinct and tactical thinking.
Stares in disbelief at the chicken feathers explosion, suggesting momentary surprise or lack of anticipation of this detail.
Navigates through chaotic crowds, dropping disguises and slipping into Chinatown, pushing his body beyond its limits.
Appears trapped in the middle of a place with no idea where enemies might be coming from.
Holds a gun on a guard to find contraband quickly, showing forcefulness but focus on the task.
Pulls Eddie along through dangerous and illegal underground locations to accomplish goal, demonstrating protectiveness and urgency.
Challenges Nugent by stating 'It crossed the line, Frank. You crossed the line,' showing moral awareness and standing ground despite pressure.
Looking at Eddie working frantically and stalling for time along with him, indicating quick situational awareness and tactical thinking.
Defends Teddy A as a good cop despite Nugent disparaging him, showing loyalty but possibly clouded judgment.
Acknowledges the fear and isolation of the old man Sam, noting that people like him have nobody and are scared to say anything.
Takes the cordless phone from Sam and sets his gun aside while in Sam's home, indicating a temporary respect or trust.
Rips off the padlock with his gun and kicks in the door to the bedroom without apparent care for the occupant's privacy or property.
Keeps calm and non-confrontational when confronted by gang members, raises hands in surrender to avoid trouble.
Withdraws from window and pulls Eddie away from danger, showing protective behavior.
Refuses to respond to Ong’s provocation and maintains cool demeanor.
Quickly disarms Ong with a precise counterattack despite his own pain; confiscates IDs and asserts control of the situation.
Uses intimidation effectively by showing his badge and threatening serious consequences.
Initially dismisses Eddie's concern about Sam opening the door but then reassesses with a slight smile.
Listens quietly and respectfully to Eddie's story, nodding thoughtfully.
Tucks his gun confidently and directs Shaquille to pull in downstairs, pop the trunk, and go home.
Looks completely confused when Eddie talks about Chuck Berry changing, fails to engage effectively.
Forces passengers to kneel face first against the windows with hands over heads for their safety.
Shows determination and protects passengers despite physical exhaustion.
Holds gun to driver to keep the bus moving and escape danger.
Hands out newspapers and duct tape to passengers to tape over windows, helping calm and protect them.
Pushing FOUR to move towards the front to cover the windshield, showing focus on protection.
Observes Eddie’s notebook filled with months of hope, craft and hard work, showing a moment of silent respect and acknowledgment.
Consoles a Latino woman with a soothing smile, demonstrating kindness and empathy.
Makes a firm demand for a DA, court stenographer, and media presence to witness testimony on the bus, threatening to start shooting otherwise, showing a harsh and intimidating approach.
Examines Eddie’s notebook, showing awareness of the kid’s careful planning and thought.
Makes a clear, confident demand via radio for the District Attorney, court stenographer, and media to board the bus to witness sworn testimony.
Sets a firm thirty-minute deadline with a credible threat to start shooting if his demands are not met, showing assertiveness and strategic pressure.
Cuts off Sheehan mid-explanation, demonstrating decisiveness and control in the situation.
Clicks off the radio after stating demands, signaling confidence and refusing to entertain negotiation, displaying command presence.
Moves to back of bus after making demands, indicating a calm and controlled posture.
Insists Eddie change clothes and leaves him to escape a deadly breach, telling him to give up testifying and accept the situation to survive.
Deceptively tells Eddie that no one is coming to rescue them to make him comply, while knowing the danger ahead.
Shows a sense of responsibility and care by trying to save Eddie’s life despite grim circumstances.
Displays resignation and lack of hope, telling Eddie it’s over and to forget fighting back, indicating emotional withdrawal.
Formulates a plan to save Eddie by having him switch clothes with another passenger and escape before the assault.
Clearly explains risks and the urgency of the situation to Eddie, showing situational awareness and decisive leadership.
Shows resignation and low hope by stating 'It's over,' indicating possible emotional or mental fatigue impacting his confidence.
Instructs passengers calmly to keep their hands visible and signals them individually when they can safely exit.
Pulls Eddie into line and adjusts his tie, showing a caring, protective gesture despite the tense situation.
Ignores Eddie’s attempt to express gratitude and urgency, focusing instead on practical advice and pushing him out for safety.
Listens to Eddie’s attempt at gratitude and shows a moment of speechlessness, indicating he is touched or surprised.
Responds sharply to Eddie calling him 'dumb shit', but does not retaliate aggressively.
Crawls to the driver’s seat and drives the bus through heavy fire and barricades to protect Eddie, showing commitment and protective behavior.
Turns back to retrieve Eddie's dropped notebook despite pressure to keep moving.
Rushes to Eddie's side after he falls, asks if he is okay.
Covers Eddie's wound with his shirt and presses on it, staying with him in a dangerous place.
Encourages Eddie to stay awake and communicate even when Eddie is near unconscious.
Notices Eddie's notebook falling, turns back to retrieve it despite holding up traffic, showing attention to detail and responsibility.
Quickly responds when Eddie falls, pulls him up and assesses his condition showing calmness under pressure.
Applies immediate first aid to Eddie's neck wound using his shirt and reassures him, demonstrating practical skill and presence of mind.
Encourages Eddie to stay awake and conscious by talking to him, indicating emotional intelligence and focus in crisis.
Initially tries to ignore the notebook on the street to keep moving faster, which could indicate hesitation or momentary poor prioritization.
Presses shirt against Eddie's neck to slow blood flow, shows concern for Eddie's wellbeing.
Tries to comfort Eddie with encouraging words about the bakery and his fate.
Seems confused at first but listens attentively to Eddie's story and feelings.
Listens carefully to Eddie's story, presses shirt to wound to slow bleeding, tries to keep Eddie conscious.
Does not fully understand Eddie's initial cryptic hints until explained.
Leans in close and sincerely urges Eddie to survive for both their sakes.
Goes to Diane’s apartment to retrieve his gun, indicating past troubled behavior acknowledged by Diane.
Reveals to Diane and Eddie his past as a self-medicating, depressed individual who ‘didn’t care about anything or anyone’.
Shows discomfort and introspection when Diane confronts him with hard truths.
Introduces Diane to Eddie despite tension; allows Diane to tend his wound, accepts care
Refuses to explain his situation to Diane when she looks for answers
Admits to being a bad person and undeserving of celebration
Asks Diane for a favor despite his injured state
Jokingly tells Eddie they won't see each other again, calls them 'two shits passing in the night'.
Shoves Eddie out of the way to protect him from gunfire.
Uses gun to smash fluorescents to create darkness and protect Eddie.
Ties up Nugent to prevent harm, distinguishing between bad guy and good guy (Eddie), showing moral clarity and protection.
Pulls gun on Eddie and forces him to run, inciting fear to ensure compliance.
Acknowledges the old man's truthfulness and mourns his death; reflects on his own corruption and pain.
Walks Eddie to a private exit and wishes him well, sharing a moment of understanding despite a guarded remark.
Refuses future contact with Eddie to protect himself emotionally, demonstrating guardedness.
Calmly contemplates a difficult moral choice and decides to face the consequences, showing resolve and awareness of the impact of his actions.
Asks Eddie for advice, indicating the capacity to seek help and reflect before acting.
Is present in tense, critical situations but remains composed and focused, demonstrating confidence under pressure.
Offers to take the place of Mr. Bunker and provides crucial information about witness tampering, including names and cases.
Requests to expunge Bunker’s record to give him peace, showing respect and kindness towards the deceased.
Interacts with Diane tenderly, showing concern and happiness for her happiness, accepts delay on wedding with understanding and warmth.
Spends time feeding pigeons in his cell, a gentle, peaceful action suggesting a reflective and caring nature.
Takes the effort to open a special cake decorated with meaningful local landmarks, shows emotional vulnerability by not knowing whether to laugh or cry, and shares the cake with others.
Jokes playfully with Grace about running away together.
Grace slides Tic Tacs without looking up; Jack accepts and pops a breath mint, ignoring work reminder.
Shows mild inattentiveness by ignoring a work-related remark about wire request paperwork.
Shoves the pick up slip through the slot without unnecessary discussion and insists on proceeding without waiting an hour for a suit.
Jerks Eddie to his feet and orders him to get dressed despite Eddie’s hesitation about the missing suit.
Ignores Eddie's possible concerns, forcibly cuffs him, shoves his head down into a car door.
Keeps walking in stony silence despite Eddie noticing his limp.
Sneaks a look at Eddie scribbling in his book during the ride.
Yanks Eddie to the sidewalk to protect him from traffic and tries to get his bearings in a chaotic situation.
Flinches at a bike messenger and becomes overly wary of bystanders, indicating heightened anxiety and possible loss of control.
Attempts to navigate the delivery alley while trying to shake off fuzziness and remember what to do next, showing some struggle but persistence.
Quickly pulls bar owner Dominic Forlini out of harm's way when a baseball bat is thrown at him, demonstrating alertness and protective instincts.
Knows exactly where the phone is in an unfamiliar bar and uses it to call dispatch with relevant details despite shaky fingers, showing presence of mind under pressure.
Responds calmly to Nugent's teasing and concern about the safety of another character.
Hesitates and appears uncomfortable as Nugent addresses him, showing internal conflict.
Does not prevent Eddie from being grabbed by Mulvey and Torres despite noticing Eddie's fear and recognition.
Works a strong program at the farm, indicating attempts at rehabilitation or self-improvement.
Half-listens and watches as Mulvey roughs up Eddie, saying 'He’s clean.'
Observes harsh treatment of Eddie silently without intervening.
Backing Eddie towards the rear door, ensuring his safety during a tense situation.
Holding Nugent’s stare, trying to hold it together, showing emotional struggle and sincerity.
Discards shotgun info down a drain, saying it’s been with him for twenty years and lucky it went off.
Backing Eddie and another person cautiously towards the rear door while holding Nugent’s stare and trying to hold it together under pressure.
Dropping the shotgun info a drainage grate after assessing its usefulness and explaining there was only one shell for twenty years.
Appears shaken and momentarily unclear about what Eddie saw, indicating some initial disorientation.
Calms the surprised laundry owner in halting Chinese, showing situational awareness and interpersonal skill.
Unlocks Eddie’s cuffs and discreetly changes his clothing to help him blend in, showing resourcefulness and practical skill.
Instructs Eddie to walk confidently and stay close, demonstrating tactical thinking and protective vigilance.
Keeps eyes alert and scans surroundings carefully while escorting Eddie through the streets, showing situational awareness and protective diligence.
Trying to control pace and searching for a cab to expedite their movement.
Eddie accuses Jack of having no idea what he's doing, indicating uncertainty or lack of clarity in Jack's approach.
Immediately responds to a threat by taking control and disarming Torres, protecting Eddie.
Shows a flash of hurt and sadness when looking at clothes but quickly hides it.
Roughly drops Torres onto the bed after subduing him.
Grabs Eddie's hand to pull him onto the platform, protecting him from danger.
Uses a sarcastic insult ('IQ of a sprinkler head') towards Eddie while under stress.
Responds honestly when asked about his past, showing some openness.
Still helps Eddie escape despite past differences and dangers.
Chuckles and engages in light-hearted banter with Eddie about birthday cakes and a bakery plan.
Keeps his gun ready and eyes peeled, tense and exasperated, showing distrust and suspicion.
Keeps his finger on his gun, stays alert while navigating traffic and tense situation.
Gives clear, tactical directions to the cab driver (make a left at Broome, come in the back).
Expresses exasperation to himself but acknowledges responsibility ('I’m the guy').
Engages in light banter with Eddie, showing some distraction from the situation but still aware.
Checks traffic conditions carefully, assesses the situation with repair crews funneling lanes, keeps track of time, and racks his brain trying to figure out next move.
Takes a quick and decisive action by stopping Eddie from dialing, tossing money to the cab driver, opening the door while cab is moving, and pulling Eddie out into a crowd to avoid pursuers.
Shows some self-deprecating humor and perspective on plans not working out, acknowledging the unpredictability and difficulty of changing one’s nature.
Avoids asking unnecessary questions and reads Eddie’s character well (identifying him as a thief who will continue to be a thief).
Navigates a complex rooftop escape route while evading a police grid search despite his limp.
Keeps tension and readiness high, shows awareness of surroundings (e.g., observing cops through the window).
Struggles physically to keep pace due to injury but pushes through showing determination rather than optimal physical capability.
Jack falling to his knees catching sight of Maldonado on the far roof and continuing to try to move despite a bullet wound in his hand.
Jack hesitates before moving over the edge of the roof with pigeons flying around, showing caution but also some indecision.
Pulls himself up after falling into a dumpster, showing resilience and a hint of a smile.
Pulls himself out after falling into a pile of feathers and keeps moving forward despite injury.
Moves quickly through crowded and chaotic environments while injured.
Appears trapped and unable to identify threat directions in a chaotic environment.
Shoves Eddie aside to take a shot at Nugent, then glares at Eddie after Nugent threatens.
Races back and closes steel door to block Mulvey's gun, protecting himself and Eddie from immediate danger.
Recalls and leads team through a known but hidden location using past knowledge.
Races back to roll a steel door closed to block a gun-wielding assailant, physically resisting the weapon.
Pushes a companion to the side to take a firing position and return fire.
Maintains composure under gunfire, signals for silence to avoid detection.
Glares at Eddie after a careless comment during a dangerous situation, indicating awareness of threats.
Shares a light moment with Nugent about gum, causing him to grin.
Whispers encouragement to Eddie during a tense moment.
Remains silent when Nugent seeks explanation, showing distance.
Glances at his watch and assesses surroundings quietly.
Whispers instructions to Eddie to try opening the rusted elevator door.
Maintains calm and stays alert to sounds and movements around him.
Does not respond directly to Nugent's questions and remains silent on risky topics.
Objects to Nugent crossing ethical boundaries, implying a sense of justice and moral lines.
Defends Teddy A as a good cop despite Nugent's criticism.
Crawls through dust and debris under heavy gunfire, quickly acting to send the elevator up, evading danger with presence of mind.
Drops his head after Nugent's challenge, appearing momentarily defeated or unsure.
Frantically banging on doors to find a place to hide and protect himself and Eddie.
Showing his police badge and requesting entry to help and protect an elderly man.
Chaining the door to protect the old man and themselves from danger.
Putting his finger to his mouth to signal silence, trying to avoid alarming the old man but preparing for confrontation.
Taking initiative to find a phone by forcefully opening a locked door despite potential disruption.
Rips off the padlock with his gun and kicks in the door, confidently searches the room and correctly identifies the likely gang connection to the stash.
Takes the cordless phone from the kitchenette recognizing its importance and puts his gun on a table near the front door, showing situational awareness.
Moves toward the back and dials a specific phone number, showing purposeful and professional behavior.
Does not calm or address Sam’s visible distress or the tension of the moment overtly, instead proceeding with tasks in a detached manner.
Calls Dan MacDonald to coordinate the witness being protected and indicates awareness of obstacles (cops blocking the way).
Admits to MacDonald that he is about seven blocks away and stuck because police are interfering.
Shows some frustration but understands the urgency and communicates the situation clearly to MacDonald.
Identifies a leak within the squad, showing awareness of betrayal and situational danger.
Maintains calm and non-aggressive posture when confronted by armed gang members, communicates clearly that they want no trouble and only to leave.
Does not immediately react violently or escalate confrontation with gang members despite physical threat.
Shows a slight trace of a smile when looking at Eddie differently.
Acknowledges limitation by saying 'Can’t fix everything' when Eddie accuses him of wanting to leave a man behind.
Rejects friendship by saying 'He ain’t my friend' and distances himself from another character.
Sincerely explains the corrupt actions of police detectives intimidating witnesses for profit, showing awareness and perhaps implicit condemnation.
Waits calmly with Eddie in a tense situation, showing patience and steadiness rather than panic.
Keeps eyes hard and fixated on the street during questioning, showing guardedness and emotional distance.
Keeps eyes and ears open while descending stairs, staying alert despite a pronounced limp.
Explains the long-term witness tampering scheme conscisely and knowledgeably, indicating intelligence and insight.
Maintains composure and watches the chaotic wedding procession quietly and patiently, demonstrating situational awareness.
Shows reluctance or emotional difficulty addressing certain issues, taking time to respond.
Admits 'Can't fix everything' implying acceptance of limited control rather than taking action to improve the situation.
Maintains focus and watches the street carefully while narrating complex past events, showing situational awareness.
Fails to be with Eddie when the large family emerges and is later not found with Eddie, indicating a possible lapse in coordination.
Laughs along with Eddie despite their dire situation.
Expresses cynicism and distrust about getting help and about Eddie's role as a 'rat'.
Engages in friendly banter with Eddie, teasing him about changing from thief to baker.
Listens attentively to Eddie's story, nods thoughtfully, and prompts Eddie to check again at the shoe shine stand.
Does not dismiss Eddie’s ideas or efforts despite Eddie’s uncertain plans and past failures.
Expresses skepticism about people changing, suggesting a cynical outlook.
Shows discomfort around Salma, indicating tension but refrains from escalating conflict.
Disagrees with Eddie's idea to leave women behind, implying a respect for women and a critical stance on unfairness.
Provides a realistic, experienced perspective about human behavior based on 23 years of police work.
Maintains professionalism despite obvious tension with Salma, showing emotional control.
Displays discomfort and stops conversation when confronted with Salma’s hostile glare.
Keeps focus on practical needs (demanding air), maintains awareness of environment in confined space (trunk).
Engages with Eddie’s humming and singing, showing mental presence and ability to follow along cognitively.
Mocks Eddie for singing the song to stay brave, reflecting skepticism rather than empathy.
Demonstrates some impatience and dismissiveness, but remains mentally clear and collected in a stressful situation.
Suddenly aware he’s hurt Eddie’s feelings and tries to address it.
Jams accelerator and pushes Shaquille out the door to avoid harm to Eddie and himself.
Positions passengers strategically to cover the windshield and windows, thinks quickly to gather newspapers and duct tape to obscure visibility for safety.
Leads calmly through the bus aisle despite frightened and distressed passengers, maintaining control of the situation.
Mumbles a prayer in Chinese to calm a fearful passenger, showing emotional intelligence and cultural awareness.
Instructs Sheehan to throw the radio despite Sheehan expressing hesitation, demonstrating decisiveness under pressure.
Stands alone inside the bus, seemingly resigned to his fate, showing no active resistance or attempt to change his situation.
Crawling to the driver's seat, starting the bus, and accelerating to break through barricades while under heavy gunfire.
Hearing the commotion, peering out to observe the situation despite limited visibility and confusion.
Momentarily speechless while processing Eddie’s unexpected actions and words.
Notices a metal sign indicating a service alley and uses it as an escape route under fire.
Swings the bus wheel hard left to take a sharp turn, managing to maintain control despite the bus lifting off the ground and landing hard with sparks.
Attempts to maneuver the bus through a clearly undersized alleyway at high speed, resulting in the bus getting wedged and damaged.
Leans in close and speaks encouragingly to Eddie, showing presence of mind and emotional support under pressure.
Obtains his gun from Diane's apartment despite risks, indicating resourcefulness and readiness.
Avoids direct confrontation with Diane but admits to personal struggles when questioned, showing honesty but also vulnerability.
Fails to explain his situation clearly to Diane when asked for an explanation.
Maintains composure and asks Diane for another favor despite his injured state.
Acknowledges his flaws and refuses to embellish his life with false optimism, showing self-awareness and realism.
Does not defend himself or his character when Eddie insults him in front of Diane.
Nods and understands Eddie’s hopeful perspective, maintaining a long silence without dismissing him outright.
Stares into space, reflecting on personal mistakes and the lack of second chances, showing vulnerability.
Expresses cynicism about eventual justice or good outcomes ('Eventually is a bunch of--'), suggesting guardedness.
Reflects on past mistakes with a sense of realism and caution, showing thoughtful self-awareness.
Nods in understanding to Eddie's hopeful viewpoint, showing emotional intelligence and openness.
Attempts to listen for outside activity, showing alertness and situational awareness.
Does not take any immediate action or communicate further despite suspicious police presence and unfolding confrontation.
Shoves Eddie out of the way as gunfire erupts, firing his weapon and seeking cover.
Uses his gun to smash the fluorescents to plunge the area into darkness, aiding their stealth and evasion.
Moves silently and stays low while guiding Eddie through the garage, demonstrating tactical awareness.
Stops and checks his watch before approaching the doors, showing situational attentiveness.
Shoves Eddie inside the car, removes the cuffs, and cracks the window to provide fresh air.
Instructs Eddie to stay put and gives clear, protective escape directions.
Leads pursuers away from Eddie, prioritizing Eddie's safety over his own.
Quietly shuts the door and stays low while moving away from Eddie to avoid detection.
Leads Mulvey away and successfully takes him down with a well-timed and forceful attack.
Uses the environment skillfully to ambush Torres, knocking him out before he can react.
Attempts to lure Nugent out and anticipates his movements, showing tactical awareness.
Does not fully close the door after putting Eddie inside the car, which could risk exposure.
Successfully disarms Nugent by pressing a .38 revolver to his ear, preventing him from shooting.
Drags Nugent into church and effectively restrains him with a torn curtain cord.
Maintains calm and control throughout the tense situation, using intimidation and timing to his advantage.
Asks Father Connelly to trust him and tries to set the record straight despite risks.
Carefully tends to Eddie’s wound and shows concern for his survival.
Admits to using Eddie and risking his life to do what he could not do himself.
Shares painful, honest confession about past involvement in wrongdoing and shows emotional pain.
Asks Father Connelly to trust him and attempts to set the record straight, showing honesty and a desire to take responsibility.
Walks to Eddie, tending to his wound despite Jack's own pain, showing practical care and presence of mind.
Admits he used Eddie and took a great risk to protect others, showing self-awareness and strategic thinking.
Reflects emotionally on past violent events, showing vulnerability but no clear indication of poor competence.
Expresses confusion and sorrow but does not take immediate actionable steps in this excerpt.
Walks out of a situation of truth and death silently, following a mentor's corrupt example, showing emotional resignation.
Reflects deeply on his moral and professional decline, acknowledging his brokenness and corruption.
Chooses to remain a cop despite disillusionment and pain, indicating persistence and underlying professional commitment.
Offers Eddie guidance and a way out, calmly coordinating departure through safer route.
Keeps emotional pain and doubts internalized, smiling and speaking cryptically to Eddie.
Considers giving keys to his best friend to help the woman of Eddie's dreams, showing trust and selflessness.
Takes a deep breath and acknowledges the personal pain of his decisions but stands by them, indicating sincerity and integrity.
Accepts that he may never feel good but still acts on principle, showing responsibility and moral warmth.
Smiles and jokes with Father Connelly despite tense situation.
Hums quietly to himself while under threat, showing calmness and possibly friendliness.
Allows Father Connelly and a uniform to help him after injury, receptive to assistance.
Maintains calm composure under threat, even hums unconcernedly while a sniper targets him.
Does not immediately take cover or react to sniper attack, resulting in being shot and injured.
Cuts open a package carefully and inspects its contents with mixed emotions; samples the icing on the cake thoughtfully; shares the cake with others by inviting Bernie and Ted to try it.
Fails to notice the picture falling from the box onto the floor.
